Legal_Issue: Credibility of claimant and subjective fear in refugee claim
Credibility_Assessment: Testimony contained inconsistencies and omissions
Evidence_Type: Oral testimony, psychologist's report, application documents
Legal_Provision: s. 96, s. 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of credibility and subjective fear
Decision_Maker: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court
Application_Error: Omission of key details in application
Evidence_Ignored: Psychologist's report did not address credibility gaps
Application_Factor: Duplicative claims under s. 96 and s. 97
Document_Fraud: Inconsistent statements in application and testimony

Violation_Type: Credibility assessment without considering corroborating evidence
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), sections related to refugee protection and procedural fairness
Governing_Law: Canadian immigration law, particularly IRPA and the principles of procedural fairness in administrative decision-making
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed persecution in Bangladesh due to political activities; submitted testimony, psychological report indicating PTSD, and letters supporting political involvement and police issues
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged fabrication of testimony by the claimant, as determined by the Refugee Division
Procedural_Issue: Failure to consider all relevant evidence, including psychological and corroborating documents, before rejecting the claim
Evidence_Used: Personal testimony, psychological report on PTSD, letters supporting political involvement and police persecution
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Panel did not address the psychological report or supporting letters in its decision
Credibility_Assessment: Panel dismissed claimant's testimony as fabricated without analyzing objective corroborating evidence
Decision_Outcome: Refugee Division rejected the applicants' claims based on credibility
Outcome: Federal Court allowed judicial review, found error in assessment
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the Refugee Divisionâ€™s decision
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of the refugee claim by a new panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard in administrative law; obligation to consider all relevant evidence under IRPA
Decision_Rationale: The panel failed to properly assess credibility by disregarding independent corroborating evidence, violating procedural fairness
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Violation_Type: Failure to establish well-founded fear of persecution
Application_Facts: Applicants delayed claiming refugee status for seven weeks, citing hope for peace; Board found this inconsistent with testimony; no documentary evidence supporting claims of older Tamils being arrested in 2000
Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence regarding conditions in Sri Lanka in 2000
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No documentation supporting arrest of older Tamils in 2000
Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicants not credible due to inconsistencies and implausible explanation for delay
Remedy_Sought: Certification of question of general importance
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution or risk of cruel treatment under IRPA
Decision_Rationale: Delay in claiming refugee status undermined subjective fear; lack of credible and supporting evidence; Board's findings within acceptable range of outcomes

Legal_Provision_Violated: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed fear of persecution in Turkey based on ethnicity, religion, and political opinion
Procedural_Issue: Board failed to meaningfully consider psychological report in credibility assessment
Evidence_Used: Dr. Devins' psychological report diagnosing chronic posttraumatic stress disorder
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of discussion on relevance of PTSD diagnosis to credibility
Credibility_Assessment: Board questioned applicant's credibility but did not adequately address impact of mental health condition
Decision_Outcome: Board dismissed claim primarily due to credibility concerns
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of refugee claim by a different panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Patent unreasonableness standard for credibility findings
Decision_Rationale: Board's failure to analyze medical evidence affecting credibility was clearly unreasonable

Legal_Issue: Subjective fear of persecution in refugee claim
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; refugee claim denied
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's explanations for delay deemed unpersuasive; legal background and consultation with lawyer undermined credibility
Evidence_Type: Personal testimony, legal consultation records, applicant's conduct
Legal_Provision: Section 96 and Section 97 of IRPA regarding refugee protection
Key_Factor_in_Determination: 14-month delay in filing claim and lack of credible justification
Decision_Maker: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court
Application_Error: Failure to file claim without delay and provide satisfactory explanation for delay
Legal_Standard: Subjective fear of persecution must be genuine
Application_Factor: Delay in filing, applicantâ€™s conduct and background

Legal_Issue: Credibility assessment in refugee claim
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish credible basis for fear
Credibility_Factor: Inconsistencies in testimony, impact of PTSD on recall
Legal_Rule: Credibility assessments must be reasonable and justified
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of blood feud in Albania
Legal_Framework: IRPA, Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Outcome: Decision quashed, case referred to differently constituted RPD

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making false statements for the purpose of procuring a passport
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Administrative dispute over passport service refusal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the five-year refusal of passport services was reasonable based on provision of false information
Crimes.Outcome: Federal Court dismissed the application for judicial review; refusal upheld
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Adjudicator found the errors in application were intentional despite applicant's claim of no intent to mislead
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Passport application documents, custody and relationship status information
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections 9 and 10 of the Canadian Passport Order
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Provision of false information regarding relationship and custody status in passport application
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Intentionality of false statements and need for dissuasion and proportionality
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Passport Canada adjudicator, reviewed by Federal Court
Crimes.Application_Error: False information about cohabitation and custody of child
Crimes.Legal_Standard: No requirement to prove intent to defraud under Canadian Passport Order
Crimes.Application_Factor: False declaration in support of childâ€™s passport application
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Five-year refusal of passport services upheld
Crimes.Authority: Passport Canada under the Canadian Passport Order
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False statements in official passport application form

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Administrative dispute over passport service refusal based on incomplete or false application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the five-year refusal based on false or incomplete application was reasonable
Crimes.Outcome: Federal Court upheld the five-year ban on passport services
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Adjudicator determined the application was intentionally incomplete or false
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Passport application records, residency and custody claims
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Canadian Passport Order provisions on false information
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Submission of false information regarding cohabitation with child's mother
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Materiality of false information and deterrence
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Passport Canada adjudicator, subject to Federal Court review
Crimes.Application_Error: Falsely claiming joint residence with child's mother
Crimes.Legal_Standard: No requirement to prove intent to mislead for refusal of services
Crimes.Application_Factor: Inaccurate information provided in child's passport application
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False declarations in passport application documents

Legal_Issue: Was the Board's decision to reject Mr. Bohorquez's refugee claim reasonable based on credibility findings?
Outcome: The application for judicial review is allowed, and the case is remitted for re-determination by a different panel.
Credibility_Assessment: The Board overlooked key evidence (threat to mother, land registry system misunderstanding, FARC's tracking ability), leading to unreasonable credibility findings.
Basis_of_Claim: Mr. Bohorquez claimed refugee status due to threats from FARC after refusing to inflate property values.
Application_Error: Overlooked key evidence in credibility assessment
Legal_Standard: The Board must reasonably assess evidence and consider all relevant facts when making credibility determinations.
Application_Factor: Unreasonable credibility findings due to ignored evidence
Decision_Outcome: Board's decision overturned; case remitted for re-evaluation by new panel

Legal_Issue: Does the applicant meet the tripartite test for a stay of removal?
Outcome: The applicant does not meet the criteria for a stay of removal; the motion is dismissed.
Credibility_Assessment: The applicant failed to prove unusual hardship or personalized risk in Ukraine. Claims were assessed multiple times, finding no significant risk.
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to establish irreparable harm and serious question to be tried; balance of convenience did not favor applicant.
Proceeding_Type: Federal Court application for stay of removal
Assessment_Standard: Tripartite test: (a) serious question to be tried, (b) irreparable harm if injunction not granted, (c) balance of convenience favors applicant.
Legal_Standard: Tripartite test for stay of removal
Application_Factor: Unsuccessful prior immigration applications, repeated assessments of risk, lack of evidence of persecution or hardship
Decision_Outcome: Application for stay of removal dismissed

Crime_Name: Administrative Error in Visa Application Process
Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer correctly applied s. 78(4) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations in assessing Mr. Marr's educational credentials
Governing_Law: Section 78(4) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Outcome: The officer erred by failing to consider special circumstances under s. 78(4); decision set aside and application remitted for reconsideration
Evidence_Type: Educational credential, duration of study, information on Scotlandâ€™s education system
Legal_Provision: s. 78(4), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Basis_of_Claim: Insufficient points awarded due to misapplication of regulations regarding educational credentials
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Officer failed to consider special circumstances such as shorter education system in Scotland
Decision_Maker: Visa officer, later reviewed by Federal Court
Application_Error: Incorrect point allocation (15 instead of 20) for educational credential
Evidence_Ignored: Potential relevance of Scotlandâ€™s shorter post-secondary education system
Application_Factor: Two-year post-secondary credential with 13 years of study (not meeting 14-year threshold)
Decision_Outcome: Application refused initially; decision quashed and remitted for re-evaluation

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant re-entered Canada after deportation and reported home break-ins and threats from Delroy Wright

Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to re-entry after deportation

Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed, decision set aside
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: New evidence or risk developments post-RPD decision under section 113 IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Unclear analysis of new evidence despite submission of alleged new risks

Legal_Issue: Did the Board misinterpret s. 2(3) of the Immigration Act and fail to apply it properly?
Outcome: The application is allowed, and the matter is returned for redetermination by a new panel due to the Board's legal error.
Basis_of_Claim: Mr. Jiminez claimed refugee status based on past persecution in El Salvador, but the Board rejected his claim.
Application_Error: Focused on current psychological state post-brain injury rather than nature of past persecution
Evidence_Ignored: Severity and appalling nature of past torture in El Salvador
Legal_Standard: Whether the Board correctly applied s. 2(3)
Application_Factor: Compelling reasons arising from past persecution

Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Board failed to consider severity of past persecution

Evidence_Source: Testimony of Mr. Jiminez regarding torture
Basis_for_Decision: Severe torture suffered in the past
Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Failure to assess compelling reasons under s. 2(3)

Dispute_Type: Credibility and risk assessment in refugee claim

Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to credibility and state protection findings

Application_Factor: Commitment to community work under threat
Decision_Outcome: Decision quashed, matter remitted for new determination

Violation_Type: Failure to properly assess subjective fear
Misapplication of country conditions in risk assessment
Procedural error in timing of departure evaluation
Governing_Law: Standard of review: patent unreasonableness for factual findings, correctness for legal issues
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed refugee status based on fear of persecution; risk confirmed in May 2001; delayed departure from Italy due to late confirmation of danger
Residency_Compliance: Lawfully present in Italy prior to claiming refugee status
Procedural_Issue: Member failed to adequately consider country conditions and credibility of subjective fear
Evidence_Used: Personal testimony regarding fear of persecution
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Dismissal of country conditions without proper linkage to objective risk
Credibility_Assessment: Subjective fear deemed not credible by Member, but court found this assessment patently unreasonable
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim initially denied by Immigration and Refugee Board
Legal_Standard_Applied: Separate consideration of protection needs under Section 97
Assessment of subjective and objective components of risk
Decision_Rationale: Delay in departure was reasonable given timing of risk confirmation; country conditions must inform objective risk even if subjective fear is questioned

Legal_Issue: Whether Apotex is required to address AstraZeneca's '762 Patent under the NOC Regulations
Evidence_Assessment: Timing of marketing post-NOC issuance, product specificity of the patent
Burden_of_Proof: On Apotex to demonstrate improper listing
Legal_Rule: Subsection 5(1) of the NOC Regulations requires generic manufacturers to address patents listed on the register if the drug was marketed in Canada pursuant to an NOC
Grounds_for_Claim: Improper patent listing due to timing and product specificity
Key_Evidence_Considered: AstraZeneca's listing of the '762 Patent against multiple NOCs, Minister's determination on marketing timing
Legal_Framework: Regulatory framework for patent listing under NOC Regulations
Defendant_Response: Apotex argued the patent was improperly listed
Evidence_Type: Regulatory filings, patent register entries, NOC records
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to overturn Minister's decision

Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Section 96-97
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed fear of persecution due to perceived Darod clan membership despite actual Hawiye lineage; raised in environment where she was perceived as Darod
Procedural_Issue: Refugee Board failed to consider evidence on perceived social group membership
Evidence_Used: Evidence regarding upbringing, family dynamics, and perception of clan affiliation
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board ignored or disregarded relevant evidence on perceived clan membership
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim initially dismissed by Refugee Board
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution based on membership in a particular social group
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, correctness for questions of law
Decision_Rationale: Error in law occurred because Board did not assess whether applicant was perceived as member of Darod clan, which could constitute a particular social group
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court

Application_Facts: Applicants fled Bangladesh due to alleged persecution by the Awami League for involvement with the Bangladesh Nationalist Party.
Discrepancies noted between testimony and Basis of Claim Form.
Applicants did not seek asylum in the U.S. despite opportunity.
Claimant_Status: Principal Applicant and family claiming refugee protection
Residency_Compliance: Complied with Canadian immigration procedures upon entry
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged inconsistencies in testimony and documentation
Procedural_Issue: RPD failed to consider explanations for discrepancies
Overreliance on failure to claim asylum in the U.S.
Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence of political affiliation and threats
Evidentiary_Deficiency: RPD discounted documentary evidence without sufficient justification
Lack of proper explanation for discrediting applicant's account
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found applicant evasive and inconsistent
Federal Court found credibility assessment unreasonable
Decision_Outcome: RPD denied refugee status based on credibility findings
Outcome: Referred back to new RPD panel
Remedy_Sought: Reassessment by a new RPD panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution on grounds of race, religion, nationality, political opinion, or membership in a particular social group
Decision_Rationale: Explanations provided by applicants were ignored
Failure to claim asylum in the U.S. was given undue weight

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Intellectual Property / Copyright Enforcement
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the defendants breached a court order by aiding or inducing copyright infringement
Crimes.Governing_Law: Federal court order dated April 29, 1986, and principles of contempt law
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Court evaluated private detective reports, affidavits, and evidence of conduct violating the spirit and letter of the court order
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Defendants found in contempt of court
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiffs met burden by clear and convincing evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Evidence of deliberate disregard for the court order deemed credible
Crimes.Legal_Rule: A corporation must ensure compliance with court orders by its agents; actions that invite infringement constitute breach
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Abuse of discretion in contempt determinations
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Violation of a specific court injunction prohibiting copyright infringement
Key_Evidence_Considered: Sales practices indicating intent to facilitate infringement
Crimes.Legal_Framework: U.S. Federal Courts' equitable powers to enforce compliance with injunctions
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Attempted to circumvent direct liability by selling incomplete systems and denying inducement
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Fines and security deposits to ensure future compliance
Crimes.Outcome: Fines of $500 each imposed on Michael Lee and Norman Parent; $100,000 security bond required from House of Semiconductors and Microcom
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Inherent authority of courts to punish contempt and enforce orders
Crimes.Authority: Federal judiciary precedent on civil contempt and inducement of infringement

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Intellectual Property / Unauthorized Use of Software
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the defendants violated the court order by facilitating unauthorized copying of copyrighted software
Crimes.Governing_Law: Copyright Act and prior court injunction dated April 29, 1986
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Contempt and enforcement phase following initial copyright judgment
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Court assessed intent and knowledge behind distribution of tools enabling infringement
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Defendants held liable for aiding and abetting copyright infringement in violation of court order
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Clear and convincing evidence standard applied
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Defendantsâ€™ claims of non-involvement discredited due to instructional support for copying
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Selling products designed for infringement with knowledge and encouragement constitutes indirect infringement
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Abuse of discretion in interpreting compliance with injunctive relief
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Inducement and material contribution to copyright infringement despite court ban
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Liability established for indirect infringement under the guise of technical compliance
Key_Evidence_Considered: Sale of computers with blank chips
Instructions provided on how to copy protected chips
Crimes.Legal_Framework: 17 U.S.C. Â§ 101 et seq., secondary liability doctrines (inducement, contributory infringement)
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Argued no direct copying was performed by them; sold only hardware components
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Penalties and financial security to deter further violations
Crimes.Outcome: Fines of $500 each on individuals; $100,000 security bonds from corporate entities; cost recovery awarded to plaintiffs
Crimes.Legal_Provision: 17 U.S.C. Â§ 502 (injunctions), common law of inducement
Crimes.Authority: Precedents on contributory and vicarious copyright liability

Legal_Issue: Is the decision to cancel the applicant's security clearance manifestly unreasonable?
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review under section 18.1 of the Federal Courts Act
Evidence_Assessment: The applicant had a criminal past, including impersonating a police officer. Despite providing additional information, the Advisory Body deemed her a potential risk to civil aviation based on I.4(d) of the Program.
Decision_Outcome: The decision was not manifestly unreasonable therefore, the application for judicial review was dismissed.
Legal_Rule: The applicable standard of review is patent unreasonableness due to the tribunal's expertise and legislative purpose.
Grounds_for_Claim: Criminal charges against the applicant led to the suspension and eventual cancellation of her transportation security clearance.
Outcome_on_Merits: The court rejected the application, upholding the cancellation of the security clearance.
Key_Evidence_Considered: Criminal past involving impersonating a police officer
Risk assessment under I.4(d) of the Program
Legal_Provision: section 18.1 of the Federal Courts Act

Legal_Issue: Is the decision to cancel the applicant's transportation security clearance manifestly unreasonable?
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review under section 18.1 of the Federal Courts Act
Evidence_Assessment: The applicant had a criminal record for fraud over $5000. Despite providing additional information and obtaining a conditional discharge, the Advisory Body recommended cancellation based on her criminal past and potential risk to civil aviation.
Decision_Outcome: The decision was not manifestly unreasonable the application for judicial review was dismissed.
Legal_Rule: The applicable standard of review is patent unreasonableness, considering the expertise of the tribunal, purpose of the legislation, and nature of the question.
Grounds_for_Claim: Criminal charges against the applicant led to the suspension and eventual cancellation of her transportation security clearance.
Outcome_on_Merits: The court rejected the applicant's challenge, upholding the cancellation of her security clearance.
Defendant_Response: Provided additional information and obtained a conditional discharge
Legal_Provision: section 18.1 of the Federal Courts Act

Legal_Issue: Is the decision to cancel the applicant's security clearance manifestly unreasonable?
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review under section 18.1 of the Federal Courts Act
Evidence_Assessment: The applicant had a criminal record for fraud over $5000 and was given a conditional discharge. Despite providing additional information, the Advisory Body recommended cancellation based on her criminal past and potential risk to civil aviation.
Decision_Outcome: The decision is not manifestly unreasonable therefore, the application for judicial review is dismissed.
Legal_Rule: The applicable standard of review is patent unreasonableness, considering the expertise of the tribunal, purpose of legislation, and nature of the question.
Grounds_for_Claim: Cancellation of the applicant's transportation security clearance due to her criminal history and perceived risk to civil aviation.
Outcome_on_Merits: The court rejected the application for judicial review, upholding the cancellation of the security clearance.
Legal_Framework: Dr Q v. College of Physicians and Surgeons of British Columbia
Legal_Provision: section 18.1 of the Federal Courts Act

Crime_Name: Possession of prohibited weapons or substances
Application_Facts: Mr. Cantell missed the 90-day deadline but applied within one year; claimed distraction due to his wifeâ€™s medical issues
Procedural_Issue: Application for extension of time under section 129.2(4) of the Customs Act
Evidence_Used: Seizure of wine and pepper spray at customs
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No evidence of a bona fide intention to appeal within the initial period
Relief_Sought: Extension of time to appeal seizure
Legal_Standard_Applied: Section 129.2(4) of the Customs Act: inability to act, bona fide intention, justness/equity, timely application
Decision_Rationale: Failed to meet statutory criteria under section 129.2(4); second infraction; delay; lack of equitable grounds

Crime_Name: Failure to declare goods at customs
Legal_Issue: Eligibility for extension of time under section 129.2 after missing 90-day deadline
Evidence_Assessment: Personal circumstances cited but insufficient to demonstrate bona fide intention or equitable grounds
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to meet criteria under section 129.2(4)
Legal_Rule: Extension allowed only if applied within one year and meets all conditions: inability to act, bona fide intention, just/equitable, prompt action when possible
Grounds_for_Claim: Personal issues related to wife's medical condition
Key_Evidence_Considered: Timing of application; lack of documentation supporting intent or urgency
Legal_Framework: Statutory interpretation of Customs Act provisions on appeals and extensions
Evidence_Type: Affidavit or statement regarding personal circumstances
Remedy_Requested: Extension of time to file appeal
Legal_Provision: Sections 129.1 and 129.2 of the Customs Act
Authority: Minister of Border Security and Organized Crime Reduction; Federal Court

Application_Facts: Applicants claimed refugee status based on gender and clan membership; RAD failed to consider the National Documentation Package (NDP) despite recognizing Somali citizenship law.
Procedural_Issue: RAD refused to consider all evidence, specifically the NDP; failure to independently assess country condition documents.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider the NDP, which contains critical country condition evidence.
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility issues cited as basis for rejection by RPD and upheld by RAD.
Decision_Outcome: RPD rejected claims; RAD upheld decision.
Outcome: Judicial review granted; case remanded to RAD for reconsideration by a different panel.
Remedy_Sought: Re-evaluation of refugee claim with full consideration of evidence
Decision_Rationale: RAD must independently assess all evidence, including country condition documents, rather than merely applying a reasonableness standard. Omission of NDP prevented proper assessment.
